page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised,
at
w
t
yo
r
L. letter of
e 14 of Marche, whiche came
to my handes
e 4 of this present, I receaved
one from my
LL. of
e Councel
, of
e 15 of
e
same moneth, and an other to
e
general states
:
w
t
whome I have dealt, as I hope, in suche ample
and sufficient maner, as
e importance of those
causes, and
at credit required, whiche their
LL. gave unto me. The copie of that whiche
I proposed, I have sent yo
r
L. heerew
t
, and
likewise a letter to my LL. of
e Councel, w
ch
I
humbly beseeche yow to present unto them, and
if yow finde it expedient, to recommend to
their furtherance
e autoritie of this
Councel
.
It is that, no dout, whiche would reduce the
government of these contreis, if not to a perfitte
good state, yet assuredly to suche an order, as
they should finde by the effectes, to be muche
more tolerable. W
t
all it would be a meanes,
to cutte of
e credit of suche among
e General
States, as take a special pride in contending w
t
her
Ma
tie
. I have had many charges from home,
to deale w
t
e states in this cause, and I have
used earnest speeches, to suche effect as I was
willed: But because there hath nothing folowed
uppon their careles answears, it
is
muche to be
douted, that they take it all for no other, but
for a mater of course. Although
it were come to
at point, whiche yo
r
L. doth wishe,
that
e General states could be induced to a
newe Treaty, and to put in oblivion all maner
of
former
breaches on bothe sides, acknowledging their
due debt to her Ma
tie
yet I am fully persuaded
fol.115v
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
they will depart w
t
no other places of assurance, then
they have done already, for
e remboursement of her
Hig
nes
charges. Also their publicke Act for ac-
knowledging their debt, might be somw
at
in shewe,
in respect of sundrie defalcations, uppon whiche it
is likely heereafter they will insist: but unles
her Ma
tie
were so possessed, as she is, of some cautionary
townes, I see every day by their wrangling courses,
in most mens causes, that when they are not inclined
to make satisfaction, they will never want evasions
to frustrat their Actes.
It will be a
great allegation among them, when they come to ac-
count, That her Ma
ties
assistance was never kept
complete, that
e Musters and paiments have bin
made w
t
out their privitie, that
e 15 dead paies
were never allowed by
e Contrey, and
e number
of absents ever greater, then was to be permitted, w
th
divers other objections
, whiche, all thinges conside-
red, might be particularly and very reasonablely
answeared, according to their several natures:
but I have given them hitherto a general answear,
That her Ma
tie
notw
t
standing her often and earnest soli-
citation, could never yet obtene,
at
e Councel of state
might be established in their full autoritie, whereby
she might orderly come to
e notice of those disorders,
and w
t
all resolve to cast
e whole care of refor-
mac
o
n uppon
e said Councel, to whome by agreem
t
between her Hig
nes
and
e contrey it doth only belong.
The wrong that hath bin done to her Ma
tie
and these
Provinces in
at respect, I have somw
at
dilated in this
last proposition.
Howe it may stand
w
t
her Ma
ties
suretie, to breake w
t
these contreis, as
farre as I can conceave, submitting my opinion to
yo
r
L. correction, it will very muche depend
uppon
e prosperous successe of
e
Frenche kinges
affaires.
fol.116r
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
Belgia 1590 April 18
For otherwise, if the Enemies forces should continue
in that strength, as they have bin heretofore, I see
now howe they can w
t
stand, without the helpe of her
Ma
tie
. For were it so,
at
e Generall meanes of these
Provinces, being husbanded accordingly, might en-
tertene some thousandes more in service, then are heere
at this present, as I thinke they are able, yet if her
Ma
tie
should forsake
e contrey, it is thought that
e
people would despere, and falle uppon
e soddaine
to accord w
t
e Enemie: wheras nowe on
e other side
e only name of her Ma
tie
, the Enemies opinion of
the valewe of her subjectes, and his feare of newe
supplies in time of necessitie, is a very great aide,
though there were no other. Nether is it so that
e state heere doth not thorowly see into it: But it
is supposed among them, and sometimes given out,
that her Ma
tie
of necessitie, and in regard of her
owne safetie must continue their protection. And
thus uppon
e occasions
at are offered in yo
r
L. letter,
I have said my opinion: whiche whether it be well or
ill conceaved, I trust yo
r
L. will affourde the
best construction. Heere I hold it
requisit to advertise yo
r
L. of a speciall injurie,
w
ch
is offered to her Ma
tie
by
e meanes of
M
r
Ortels
ortell no Ag
e
t
Generall
being in
England
. For it seemeth by
e letters of
her Hig
nes
and of my LL. of
e Councel, that he is
reputed there an Agent for
e Generall states of these
contreis, and that whatsover by worde or by writing,
by way of answear or otherwise, is delivered unto him,
to be imparted to
e General states, or to
e Councell
of state of these contreis, is signified accordingly.
Howbeit
e truth is, that he is
Agent
only for
e states
ortell ag
e
t
o
ly for
Holl
a
d
of Holland
, and hath no deputation from any other
Province: and therfore maketh his dispatches, not to
e
councel of state, unles it be uppon speciall requisition,
and in some special cause, but usually to
Barnevelt
the Advocat of Holland, or to
at particular Assembly,
fol.116v
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
whiche doth not keepe correspondence w
t
e Councel of
state, but taketh advantage of relating, or concealing
suche mater of his letters, as they list themselves. By
this meanes, w
at
soever her Ma
tie
my LL. of
e Councel, or
any in their behalf hath delivered unto him, to be deli-
vered heere to
e general state of
e contrey, is only
addressed to
e
states of Holland
, and by them ether
notified, or suppressed, or imparted in suche measure
as among themselves is deemed convenient. I
doe not dout, but by her Ma
ties
order there have bene
many times many thinges communicated w
t
him, about
e affaires of these contreis, w
ch
if they had bene publi-
shed heere, might have given
e state a great satis-
faction: but since my being in this place, I can not
remember above 3 or 4 letters
at he hath written
to this councel. I doe not cast
e whole fault of this
abuse, uppon M
r
Ortel himself. For he hath his commission
and entertenment from
e states of Holland, and ther-
fore bound to them only. And besides it should appeere
that he himself is not privy to this couvert kinde of
dealing, ether in Barnevelt, or in
e states of Holland.
For in his last answear to a letter whiche he sent to
e
councel of state, contening suche mater, as was deli-
vered by
M
r
Wilkes
to their late
demandes, he ma-
keth mention of former answears sent unto them,
about
e self same requestes
, w
ch
were never yet im-
parted, but ether kept backe by
e Advocat, or by
e assembly of Holland. This maner of procee-
ing hath bin used a long time, but unknowen to
e Councel heere, till it came in question
of
uppon
his last letter unto them, and uppon
e copie of
e
Articles, whiche yo
r
L. sent unto me, exhibited by
M
r
Ortel in
e name of
e General states, and
Appostilled by my LL. of
e
Councel the 15 of
Marche: w
ch
Articles and Appostils, though they con-
tene suche mater, as belongeth only to
e conduct of
e councel of state,
the
were never opened yet unto them
fol.117r
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
whereby
e Councel being ignorant w
at
had passed,
writt lately againe, about
e self same affaires.
And thus because
e General states,
e Councel of
state, and
e states of Holland, propose their causes
a part, at several times, and in divers maners,
their c
o
fused courses both putt my LL of
e Councel
to a great deale of troble, and occasion many times
that
e self same answears are not made to
e same
Propositions. For
e redresse of this disorder,
I have promised this Councel, which is muche aggrie-
ved w
t
it, to become an humble suto
r
both in their
behalfes and mine owne, that whensoever M
r
Ortel
hall solicit any mater in
e name of
e General
states, or of
e Councel of state, he may be charged
there, uppon
e receat of his answear, to send it di-
rectly and immediatly to those, to whome it is inten-
ded to be given, and not to
e states of Holland,
whiche is but one Province, wheras his negotiation
doth concerne them all. The consideration wherof,
and w
at
is convenient to be done uppon it, I refer
unto yo
r
L. wisdome, nothing douting, but if
ether in this point, or in any of
e former, there be
any thing worthy to be reported to my LL. of
e
Councel, it will be signified unto them by yo
r
honorable meanes. Howe well
this state is provided of forrene intelligence, yo
r
L.
may conjecture in
at it was more then a moneth,
before we knewe any certaintie, ether by letters or
otherwise, of
e late battaile in
Fraunce
: wherof yo
r
L. letter to me brought one of
e freshest reportes.
For whiche I thanke yo
r
L. very humbly, and for
the other pointes of yo
r
letter, whiche being very
material, and comming from yo
r
L. are both a
great c
o
fort unto me, and a special furtherance to
my service. Astouching the occur-
rences heere, there is litle
other
to be certified, but that the
Ennemie practiseth to surprise
e towne of
Berghen
.
fol.117v
Belgia 1590: Ap
r
For he increaseth his forces in those quarters, and
by common conjecture hath some intelligence in
e
towne. It is not yet knowen nor suspected w
t
whome,
but for
e Governo
rs
assistance in making enquirie
and for other needefull alterations in
e Garrison,
M
r
Gilpin
and others are sent thither. It doth ap-
peere by one of those letters, whiche were deciphred
by
Mons
r
S
t
Aldegonde
, that
e King of Spaine
doth purpose to gett
e possession of
e Dukedome of
Cleve
: for w
ch
e present opportunitie doth serve very
fitly, because
e yonge Prince is distracted, and in
a more pitifull state then
e father. Howbeit to pre-
v ent his intention
e better, there are copies of the
Kinges letters sent from hens to
e Councel of Cleve,
to
e towne of
Wesel
(w
ch
are bothe well affected)
and to their neighbo
r
Princes. We have
certaine intelligence from
Bruges
, that 3 regim
e
ts
of Wallons being newly mutined, attempted to
take a port of
at towne, and were
nerely
partly
entred
but by
e diligence of
e Burgers, there were 50 of
them slaine, and
e rest repulsed. It is
spoken heere in secret,
at
Count Hollocke
being highly
discontented w
t
e smalle regard
at is had of him by
e states, is fully resolved to take his leave of these
contreis, and to serve
e Frenche king. It is
also said among some,
at seeme to speake uppon
knowledge,
at it is heere in present deliberation,
among some principal persons, to consitute
Count
Maurice
Count of Holland.
And thus most
humbly craving yo
r
L. pardon for my tedious
discourses, I take my humble leave.
From
e
Hage
. A
p
18. 90
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
